ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Visualization and interpretation of color, composition, skills in Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop

Gained exposure to different mediums
Learned about artists working in these different mediums
Learned how artists think about material
Improved my ability to notice the visual qualities of a piece
Styles of art, composition, color theory, abstract art, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: fun, intimate, and open. projects were fairly open ended so you could take them in almost any desired direction.
Weakness: alot of the "required" supplies went unused

Strengths: group critiques, diverse and open projects, good pacing

Weaknesses: cursory lectures (not enough time spent on each artist), too many videos (not a great experience with zoom lag), weak engagement from other students (often had their video off)

I love the way the professor showcases many different works of art and gives the background on the artists who made them; I find that in a major such as Computing and the Arts, inspiration is a cornerstone of a student's motivation. I enjoyed studying the interesting examples presented in the course.

Spend less time on long videos and powerpoints and more time on student projects and techniques they can use to improve their work. Also, why is there a course fee?? We didn't spend any time in the art studio (this was a virtual course) and students purchased their own art supplies.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Presenting videos in the class was not very conducive to learning because of the lag over zoom.
I was fine with zoom learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This course is light and fun. You get to pursue open-ended prompts which allow you to explore your creative style.
I would recommend this course only if you are motivated to expose yourself to different artistic mediums and artists. Otherwise, it is easy to disengage, particularly in this virtual format.
Yes; it was interesting to view many different examples where the artist emphasized visual elements, and to experiment with creating my own in Photoshop and Adobe illustrator.
